Just like blow up dolls before them @usamiharu Yeah it's not the most refined theory. I'm not really looking at it that deep just surface level. Fan doesn't really do super deep metaphors. For example the rich guy uses and disposes dolls like they're nothing, the idol is effectively sold as a sexual object (super thinly veiled metaphor there), a club pretty much buys and then sells a girl into prostitution.  My main point is if the reader thinks this is simply erotic and fucked up they're not seeing the whole picture.

So I want to point out first I can't find any info on if Fan no Hitori is a woman or man. Artists are notorious for masking themselves HUKE always wears a mask in public for example. In fact I think Fan no Hitori is a woman seeing is the almost all of the protagonists in their stories is a woman. It's easier for a writer to write what they know and from that perspective. Second we know the writer uses parallels in their writing like how Parasite Queen is a giant metaphor for the relation between high sexual activity and STDs. So let's look at the dolls stories every person who has owned one has been pretty much looked at as a garbage person so Fan clearly doesn't want you to look positively at the situation and if you do you are equivalent to those garbage people. Not that Fan doesn't want you to get off on it. So ultimately here's what I think Fan wanted to pull from this series: This is how she sees women in Japan being treated, either that or prostitution.

@qwerqertsadafcw: As I see it, she didn't seem to have a problem with it when she was under the impression people were being picked at random. She has a reaction to seeing the government was using it to suppress resistance. I don't think that can be painted as liking/disliking orders. It's like if you were playing a game of chance only to learn the game was rigged. Suddenly your outlook on losing changes, because while you can wave off loses due to bad luck, it's different when it happens due to someone purposely fucking with the odds.
